pull.title: build:lint eliminate some lint spelling alerts
pull.body:
Eliminates another linting alert in the linting sequence.
In this case it is a false positive. "hist" is used as a variable.
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/6a7c40bee403cadedeecd4b1c6528575522094eb/contrib/seeds/makeseeds.py#L119

tree 8763902406bc9f1856b4c59332e1ddc497dcb146
parent 08e29473126d5cc4df6d2b3f368c6f6f641c0bd8

build:lint  add "hist to list of false positives

events.message: build:lint  add "hist to list of false positives

events.body:
Pretested linting prior to creating PR:
https://travis-ci.org/RandyMcMillan/bitcoin/jobs/606139243
https://travis-ci.org/RandyMcMillan/bitcoin/jobs/606139261
What is the point of this? If you want to fix typos, sure. Please go ahead and fix all of them, but this one-off change isn't worth it.
Agree, please try and avoid opening trivial PRs like this.

@MarcoFalke, @fanquake 

It seems that when I lump all these corrections into one PR then it touches too many files. I am happy to submit these either way. I am not trying to submit trivial PRs but the policy seems unclear on this. In this case what is "atomic"? A PR that changes one file? Or one PR that gets the job done? Please advise and I will submit it either way. 

Thanks for your guidance on this.

***Here are some corrections that I will handle***

![Screen Shot 2019-11-01 at 5 16 05 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/152159/68057102-54a26400-fccb-11e9-9024-480d276ee972.png)
Yeah all of them can be done in one commit

> Yeah all of them can be done in one commit

Thanks for the guidance. I will resubmit using this PR.

rename.from: build:lint  add "hist" to list of false positives
